title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement s..j.lortz@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: sspLNIRT
text: sspLNIRT package provides sample size planning tools item calibration Joint Hierarchical Model (JHM; van der Linden, 2007), combining 2-parameter normal ogive model response accuracy log-normal model response times, estimated via Gibbs sampling LNIRT package (Fox et al., 2023). core question : minimum sample size achieve desired accuracy item parameter estimates, given assumed data-generating process? accuracy defined root mean squared error (RMSE) target item parameter (e.g., discrimination α\alpha) falling user-specified threshold, averaged across items Monte Carlo iterations. detailed description method, simulation model, precomputed design conditions, see manuscript.

title: sspLNIRT
text: first step specify assumed data-generating process. includes item person parameter distributions define simulation model. following example uses 10-item test following simulation model specifications.
code: sim.mod.args <- list(   K              = 10,   mu.person      = c(0, 0),   mu.item        = c(1, 0, .5, 1),   meanlog.sigma2 = log(0.6),   sdlog.sigma2   = 0,   cov.m.person   = matrix(c(1,   0.4,                              0.4, 1), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE),   cov.m.item     = matrix(c(1, 0,   0,   0,                              0, 1,   0,   0.4,                              0, 0,   1,   0,                              0, 0.4, 0,   1), ncol = 4, byrow = TRUE),   sd.item        = c(.2, 1, .2, .5),   cor2cov.item   = TRUE )

title: sspLNIRT
text: committing design, useful inspect implied response accuracy response time distributions. helps evaluate whether assumed data-generating process plausible intended application. set N = 1e4 example. One use estimated mimum sample size well inspect distributions post hoc.   Additional views available person level:
code: do.call(plot_RA, c(list(level = "item", by.theta = TRUE, N = 1e4), sim.mod.args)) do.call(plot_RT, c(list(level = "item", logRT = FALSE, N = 1e4), sim.mod.args)) do.call(plot_RA, c(list(level = "person", by.theta = TRUE, N = 1e4), sim.mod.args)) do.call(plot_RT, c(list(level = "person", logRT = TRUE, N = 1e4), sim.mod.args))

previous_headings: Step 2: Determine the minimum sample size
title: sspLNIRT
text: run sample size optimization directly, call optim_sample(). uses bisection algorithm iteratively evaluates comp_rmse() candidate sample sizes RMSE target parameter crosses threshold. step runs full Monte Carlo simulation study iter replications. single evaluation fixed NN (without optimization), use comp_rmse():
code: # Not run — computationally intensive (several hours) library(future) plan(multisession, workers = 4)  optim.args <- list(   thresh       = 0.1,   range        = c(50, 2000),   out.par      = "alpha",   iter         = 100,   XG           = 6000,   burnin       = 20,   rhat         = 1.05,   keep.err.dat = FALSE,   seed         = 1234 )  res_alpha <- do.call(optim_sample, c(sim.mod.args, optim.args)) summary(res_alpha) # default optimizer settings opt.args <- list(N = 200, iter = 100, XG = 6000, burnin = 20,        rhat = 1.05, keep.err.dat = TRUE, seed = 1234)  # Not run — computationally intensive rmse_result <- do.call(comp_rmse, c(opt.args,sim.mod.args)) summary(rmse_result)

previous_headings: Step 2: Determine the minimum sample size
title: sspLNIRT
text: package ships precomputed minimum sample sizes across factorial grid design conditions. assumed design covered grid, results can retrieved instantly without running simulations. can use available_configs() check specifications available conditions: columns correspond design factors varied: thresh (RMSE threshold), .par (target item parameter), K (test length), mu.alpha (mean item discrimination), meanlog.sigma2 (log-scale mean σ2\sigma^2), rho (ability–speed correlation). retrieve matching result, use get_sspLNIRT(): established target accuracy α\alpha reached, can check accuracys output. item parameters RMSE threshold, thus, choose minimum sample size ouput planned sample size.

title: sspLNIRT
text: power curve shows RMSE decreases NN, fitted log-log regression optimization trace. can used extrapolate required NN target threshold thus, less variane N.min bisection optimization. can used inspect relation sample size accuracy.  left panel shows log-log fit; right panel original scale. dashed line marks threshold, dotted line extrapolated NN.
code: plot_power_curve(res_alpha$object, thresh = 0.1)

title: sspLNIRT
text: plot_estimation() shows RMSE bias varies across range true parameter values. useful identifying regions parameter space estimation less precise:
code: plot_estimation(res_alpha$object, pars = "item", y.val = "rmse") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' plot_estimation(res_alpha$object, pars = "person", y.val = "rmse") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' plot_estimation(res_alpha$object, pars = "item", y.val = "bias") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: sspLNIRT
text: full set generating parameters can inspected:
code: str(res_alpha$design) #> List of 19 #>  $ thresh        : num 0.1 #>  $ range         : num [1:2] 50 2000 #>  $ out.par       : chr "alpha" #>  $ iter          : num 100 #>  $ K             : num 10 #>  $ mu.person     : num [1:2] 0 0 #>  $ mu.item       : num [1:4] 1 0 0.5 1 #>  $ meanlog.sigma2: num -0.511 #>  $ cov.m.person  : num [1:2, 1:2] 1 0.4 0.4 1 #>  $ cov.m.item    : num [1:4, 1:4] 1 0 0 0 0 1 0 0.4 0 0 ... #>  $ sd.item       : num [1:4] 0.2 1 0.2 0.5 #>  $ cor2cov.item  : logi TRUE #>  $ sdlog.sigma2  : num 0 #>  $ item.pars.m   : NULL #>  $ XG            : num 6000 #>  $ burnin        : num 20 #>  $ seed          : num 311251 #>  $ rhat          : num 1.05 #>  $ keep.err.dat  : logi FALSE #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "sspLNIRT.design"

title: sspLNIRT
text: package includes Shiny app interactive exploration precomputed results. Users specify design conditions via interface, app retrieves corresponding minimum sample size summary statistics visualizations. Alternatively, users can specify design condition, inspect distribution visualizations, download function call R.
code: run_app()

title: sspLNIRT
text: Fox, J.-P., Klotzke, K., & Simsek, . S. (2023). R-package LNIRT joint modeling response accuracy times. PeerJ Comput Sci, 9, e1232. https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj-cs.1232 van der Linden, W. J. (2007). hierarchical framework modeling speed accuracy test items. Psychometrika, 72 (3), 287–308. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11336-006-1478-z

title: Authors and Citation
text: Sebastian Alexander Jens Lortz. Author, maintainer.

what: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
title: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
text: sspLNIRT sample size planning tool item calibration Joint Hierarchical Model (JHM) response accuracy response time. estimates minimum sample size required achieve target accuracy (RMSE) item parameter estimates specified data-generating process. package provides: Precomputed results various design conditions, accessible instantly via Shiny app /R package. Custom Sample Size Estimation via optim_sample() design conditions outside precomputed data. Visualization functions inspecting parameter accuracy bias, power curves, implied response time response accuracy distributions.

title: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
text: tool available R package interactive Shiny app.

title: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
text: Use app sebastian-lortz.shinyapps.io/sspLNIRT.

title: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
text: can install latest version R package GitHub:
code: # install devtools if needed if (!requireNamespace("devtools")) {install.packages("devtools")}  # install from GitHub devtools::install_github("sebastian-lortz/sspLNIRT")

title: Sample Size Planning for Item Calibration using the Joint Hierarchical Model
text: sspLNIRT package built R version 4.5.2 using Apple clang version 16.0.0 (clang-1600.0.26.6) GNU Fortran (GCC) 14.2.0. compile R packages source, install appropriate toolchain: macOS: see https://mac.r-project.org/tools/ Windows: see https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/

code: sspLNIRT::run_app()

text: tibble summarizing available design conditions

title: Compute RMSE of Parameters — comp_rmse
text: function computes mean squared errors estimated parameters based simulated data Joint Hierarchical Model using 2-pl normal ogive model response accuracy 3-pl log-normal model response time.

title: Compute RMSE of Parameters — comp_rmse
code: comp_rmse(   N,   iter,   K,   mu.person = c(0, 0),   mu.item = c(1, 0, 1, 1),   meanlog.sigma2 = log(0.2),   cov.m.person = matrix(c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 1), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE),   cov.m.item = matrix(c(0.2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.5, -0.35, -0.15, 0, -0.35, 0.5, 0.15, 0,     -0.15, 0.15, 0.2), ncol = 4, byrow = TRUE),   sdlog.sigma2 = 0.2,   item.pars.m = NULL,   cor2cov.item = FALSE,   sd.item = NULL,   XG = 3000,   burnin = 20,   seed = NULL,   keep.err.dat = FALSE,   rhat = 1.05 )

title: Compute RMSE of Parameters — comp_rmse
text: N Integer. sample size. iter Integer. number iterations number data sets. K Integer. test length. mu.person Numeric vector. Means theta zeta. mu.item Numeric vector. Means alpha, beta, phi, lambda. meanlog.sigma2 Numeric. meanlog sigma2. cov.m.person Matrix. covariance matrix theta zeta. cov.m.item Matrix. covariance matrix alpha, beta, phi, lambda. sdlog.sigma2 Numeric. sdlog sigma2. item.pars.m Matrix. (optional) matrix containing item parameters. cor2cov.item Logical. Whether correlation matrix instead covariance matrix supplied. sd.item Numeric vector. (optional) standard deviations alpha, beta, phi, lambda. XG Integer. number Gibbs sampler iterations. burnin Integer. burn-percentage. seed Integer NULL. Seed reproducibility. keep.err.dat Logical. Whether keep full error data. rhat Numeric. R-hat convergence cutoff.

title: Compute RMSE of Parameters — comp_rmse
text: list class `sspLNIRT.object` containing: person List `rmse` (named vector), `mc.sd.rmse` (named vector), `bias` (named vector) theta zeta. item List `rmse` (named vector), `mc.sd.rmse` (named vector), `bias` (named vector) alpha, beta, phi, lambda, sigma2. conv.rate Numeric. Proportion iterations converged (n converged / iter). err.dat List `person` `item` data frames containing per-replication errors (`keep.err.dat = TRUE`).

title: Compute RMSE of Parameters — comp_rmse
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test <- comp_rmse(   iter = 5,   N = 100,   K = 10,   mu.person = c(0, 0),   mu.item = c(1, 0, 1, 1),   meanlog.sigma2 = log(1),   cov.m.person = matrix(c(1, 0, 0, 1), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE),   cov.m.item = diag(4),   sd.item = c(.2, 1, .2, .5),   cor2cov.item = TRUE,   sdlog.sigma2 = 0.2,   XG = 2000,   keep.err.dat = FALSE,   rhat = 1.05 ) summary(test) } # }

what: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
title: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
text: function gets sspLNIRT object sspLNIRT data tibble, containing minimum sample size reach threshold root mean squared errors (RMSE) estimated parameters. sspLNIRT data precomputed using `optim_sample`. RMSE based simulated data Joint Hierarchical Model using 2-pl normal ogive model response accuracy 3-pl log-normal model response time.

title: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
code: get_sspLNIRT(thresh, out.par, K, mu.alpha, meanlog.sigma2, rho)

title: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
text: thresh Numeric. desired RMSE threshold target parameter achieved. .par Character. name target parameter threshold. K Integer. test length. mu.alpha Numeric. mean discrimination parameter alpha. meanlog.sigma2 Numeric. meanlog sigma2. rho Numeric. correlation theta zeta.

title: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
text: list containing: object sspLNIRT.object results. design design .e., set parameter values used result.

title: Get an sspLNIRT.object from the precomputed sspLNIRT data — get_sspLNIRT
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ result <- get_sspLNIRT(   thresh = .1,   out.par = "alpha",   K = 10,   mu.alpha = 1,   meanlog.sigma2 = log(.6),   rho = 0.2 ) summary(result$object) result$cfg } # }

title: Optimize for Sample Size — optim_sample
text: function optimizes minimum sample size reach threshold root mean squared errors (RMSE) estimated parameters. MSE based simulated data Joint Hierarchical Model using 2-pl normal ogive model response accuracy 3-pl log-normal model response time.

title: Optimize for Sample Size — optim_sample
code: optim_sample(   thresh,   range,   out.par = "alpha",   iter = 100,   K = 10,   mu.person = c(0, 0),   mu.item = c(1, 0, 0.5, 1),   meanlog.sigma2 = log(0.6),   cov.m.person = matrix(c(1, 0.2, 0.2, 1), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE),   cov.m.item = matrix(c(0.2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0.4, 0, 0, 0.2, 0, 0, 0.4, 0, 0.5), ncol =     4, byrow = TRUE),   sdlog.sigma2 = 0.2,   item.pars.m = NULL,   cor2cov.item = FALSE,   sd.item = NULL,   keep.err.dat = FALSE,   seed = NULL,   XG = 6000,   burnin = 20,   rhat = 1.05 )

title: Optimize for Sample Size — optim_sample
text: thresh Numeric. desired RMSE threshold target parameter achieved. range Integer vector. lower upper bounds sample size considered. .par Character. name target parameter threshold. iter Integer. number iterations number data sets. K Integer. test length. mu.person Numeric vector. Means theta zeta. mu.item Numeric vector. Means alpha, beta, phi, lambda. meanlog.sigma2 Numeric. meanlog sigma2. cov.m.person Matrix. covariance matrix theta zeta. cov.m.item Matrix. covariance matrix alpha, beta, phi, lambda. sdlog.sigma2 Numeric. sdlog sigma2. item.pars.m Matrix. (optional) matrix containing item parameters. cor2cov.item Logical. Whether correlation matrix instead covariance matrix supplied. sd.item Numeric vector. (optional) standard deviations alpha, beta, phi, lambda. keep.err.dat Logical. Whether keep full error data. seed Integer NULL. Seed reproducibility. XG Integer. number Gibbs sampler iterations. burnin Integer. burn-percentage. rhat Numeric. R-hat convergence cutoff.

title: Optimize for Sample Size — optim_sample
text: list class `sspLNIRT.object` containing: N.min Integer (character bounds met). minimum sample size achieving threshold. res.best Numeric. RMSE result optimal N. comp.rmse List. full output `comp_rmse` optimal N. trace List containing optimization diagnostics: `steps` (integer), `track.res` (data frame), `track.N` (data frame), `time.taken` (difftime).

title: Optimize for Sample Size — optim_sample
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ test.optim.sample <- optim_sample(    thresh = .1,   range = c(100, 500),   out.par = "alpha",   iter = 5,   K = 10,   mu.person = c(0, 0),   mu.item = c(1, 0, 1, 0),   meanlog.sigma2 = log(.3),   cov.m.person = matrix(c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 1), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE),   cov.m.item = matrix(c(1, 0, 0, 0,                         0, 1, 0, 0.3,                         0, 0, 1, 0,                         0, 0.3, 0, 1), ncol = 4, byrow = TRUE),   sd.item = c(.2, .5, .2, .5),   cor2cov.item = TRUE,   sdlog.sigma2 = 0.2,   XG = 1000 ) summary(test.optim.sample) } # }

title: Run the Shiny Application — run_app
text: onStart function called app actually run. needed shinyAppObj, since shinyAppDir case, global.R file can used purpose. options Named options passed runApp call (can following: "port", "launch.browser", "host", "quiet", "display.mode" "test.mode"). can also specify width height parameters provide hint embedding environment ideal height/width app. enableBookmarking Can one "url", "server", "disable". default value, NULL, respect setting previous calls  enableBookmarking(). See enableBookmarking() information bookmarking app. uiPattern regular expression applied GET request determine whether ui used handle request. Note entire request path must match regular expression order match considered successful. ... arguments pass golem_opts. See `?golem::get_golem_options` details.
